comment.author: 45586426@N06
comment._content: Two USAF planes seen on airfield rampway with protective steel revetments behind. Douglas A-1J Skyraider tail code ET of 6th Special Operations Squadron of the 633rd Special Operations Wing (based at Pleiku Air Base South Vietnam), being refuelled from out of shot airfield tanker. Last three numbers of serial on undercarriage leg covers, 016. In USAF Southeast Asia (SEA) camouflage scheme of Tan (FS30219), Dark Green (FS34079), and Medium Green (FS34102) over Light Gray (FS36622) undersides. Carrying large varied ground attack load. Numbers ‘016’ equate to the aircraft being A-1J 142016. 6th Special Operations Squadron was formed as 6th Air Commando squadron in March 1968 and disbanded in October 1969: www.skyraider.org/skyassn/skysqdhist/6sqdhist.htm Picture of A-1J 142016 in USAF service: www.nationalmuseum.af.mil/shared/media/photodb/photos/051... Douglas A-1J (Bu.No. 142016) of the 6th Special Ops in November 1968. (U.S. Air Force photo) www.flickr.com/photos/my_public_domain_photos/5548466346/ commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:A-1J_6th_SOS_over_Vietnam... 051123-F-1234P-027.jpg USAF Douglas A-1J Skyraider (U.S. Navy BuNo 142016) of 6th Special Operations Squadron over Vietnam. The 6th SOS operated from Pleiku and Da Nang air bases South Vietnam 1968 to 1969. It was deactivated on 15 November 1969 and its aircraft turned over to the South Vietnamese Air Force (VNAF). National Museum of the U.S. Air Force photo 051123-F-1234P-027 Picture of A-1J 142016 in action: www.nationalmuseum.af.mil/shared/media/photodb/photos/051... skyraider.org/skyassn/otherpics/hegre/hegre.htm Douglas A-1J (Bu.No. 142016) of the 6th Special Ops. (U.S. Air Force photo) This Douglas A-1J Skyraider originally served with the US Navy from the 1950s and flew off aircraft carriers both in peace time and combat during the Vietnam War. After retirement from the US Navy and storage, it was acquired by the US Air Force, then overhauled modified and repainted for service in the South East Asia. 1965 picture of A-1J Skyraider 142016 with US Navy on approach to a Japanese airfield: www.gonavy.jp/bbs2-a1.html Look for picture titled; A-1J 142016/NH-501 CVA-63 Kitty Hawk (Dec.27, 1965) PAPPY No.3245 (Click on pic to view) A-1J 142016. VA-115 Modex 501 tail code NH of CVW-11 CVA-63 USS Kitty Hawk dated December 27 1965 A 1965-1966 record for A-1J 142016: www.gonavy.jp/CV-CV63-01f.html www.gonavy.jp/CVW11-NH1965.html A-1J 142016 was with VA-115 'Arabs' as Modex 501 as part of Carrier Air Wing Eleven (CVW-11) tail code NH, while embarked on CVA-63 USS Kitty Hawk from October 19 1965 to June 13 1966 for a Vietnam War deployment. (info courtesy of Takafumi Hiroe, citizen of Japan and naval aviation historian) After hard use by two US military services Douglas A-1J Skyraider 142016 was transferred to then Vietnam Air Force but its fate is unknown. Probably lost in the war or if survived, captured by the invading North Vietnamese 1973-1975. ………………………………………………………………………………………………… To the left is tail end of a Douglas AC-47B ‘Spooky’ tail code EN, upper side in USAF Southeast Asia (SEA) camouflage scheme with entire undersurface in flat black. Marking on tail interpreted as AF 43 801. The aircraft belonged to the 4th Special Operations Squadron, of the 14th Special Operations Wing, based at Nha Trang Air Base in the then South Vietnam between 8 March 1966 & 14 October 1969. The unit was equipped with the AC-47 and used tail code EN. This was a specialist gunship conversion for service in Vietnam armed with three port side mounted multi-barrel miniguns plus flare dispensers. After internet research a match with serial number records reveals the aircraft to be 43-48801. [my thanks to Professor Joe Baugher of Chicago, Illinois] www.joebaugher.com/usaf_serials/1943_2.html Douglas C-47B-5-DK 43-48801 (c/n 14617/26062) to EC-47B then FC-47D *Puff the Magic Dragon*. Redesignated AC-47B USAF Picture of 43-48801 included on this webpage inside a hangar: www.chrissmithson.com/Exteriors.htm (Spooky (SN 43-48801) tail number 801. According to his log, my father flew this aircraft several times) This photo appears to have been shot from the window of another AC-47. Another picture of 43-48801: www.nationalmuseum.af.mil/shared/media/photodb/photos/051... Takeoff of Douglas AC-47D (S/N 43-48801) of the 3rd Special Operations Squadron, 14th Special Operations Wing, at Bien Hoa Air Base in August 1968. Note the left main landing gear is about 50 percent retracted. (U.S. Air Force photo) AC-47D ‘Spooky’ info: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Douglas_AC-47_Spooky www.uswarplanes.net/c47.html www.ac-119gunships.com/ac47/gunshipac47.htm www.nationalmuseum.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=3211 www.ruudleeuw.com/spooky-info.htm www.ais.org/~schnars/aero/gunships.htm AC-47D; 53 converted from C-47 (an incomplete list of AC-47 conversions includes 43-48801) Internet record for 43-48801 via this internet website: www.aerotransport.org/php/go.php In 1969 the USAF turned over its AC-47Ds to the Vietnam Air Force (VNAF) under the "Vietnamization" program. 43-48801 was transferred to the VNAF, and its ultimate fate is obscure.

comment.author: 45586426@N06
comment._content: The oddly shaped items under the outer wing are CBU-25 (cluster bomb unit) or SUU-14/A dispensers Each of the six tubes contained baseball sized bomblets dispensed out the rear of the tube. The CBUs were released one tube per press of the pickle button allowing several passes. www.skyraider.org/hook/weapons.html SUU-14/A resembled a bundle of six pipes strapped together, with a cap on the front end to hold them together. It ejected the submunitions out the rear.
